question_category.name: Default for Pre-assessment on Your Current Practices
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Pre-assessment on Your Current Practices'.

question.name: q1
question.questiontext: I am familiar with the backgrounds and lived experiences of adult ELs in my program.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q2
question.questiontext: I am aware of the strengths adult ELs bring to my classes.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q3
question.questiontext: I can assess learners’ needs.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q4
question.questiontext: I choose topics that are relevant to students' lives and goals.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q5
question.questiontext: I make sure to promote high-order and critical thinking in my lessons.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q6
question.questiontext: I can create learning objectives based on learners' communicative needs.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q7
question.questiontext: I can make effective use of authentic materials (infographics, articles, videos) in my lessons for

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q8
question.questiontext: I can sequence communicative activities from accuracy focused to fluency focused.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q9
question.questiontext: I can integrate the four skills (listening, speaking, reading, and writing) in my lessons.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q10
question.questiontext: I use a variety of classroom routines.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q11
question.questiontext: I maximize opportunities for meaningful collaboration among adult ELs in my classes.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q12
question.questiontext: I monitor my teacher talk time and maximize students’ opportunities for speaking practice.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q13
question.questiontext: I create opportunities for learners to get to know each other.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question.name: q14
question.questiontext: I can differentiate classroom tasks and assessments to meet a variety of learner needs.

answer.answertext: This is an area I need to work on in my practice.

question_category.name: Default for LRCT5.2SB1
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'LRCT5.2SB1'.

question.name: s1
question.questiontext: Which of these statements is not a guiding principle to promote a culturally inclusive class?

answer.answertext: Choose materials reflective of learners in your classes
Respond to comments or acts that are offensive or dis-affirming as they occur in class
Promote one language standard that all learners are expected to adhere to
answer.feedback: Correct! Not all learners learn the same way or at the same pace. Culturally inclusive instruction values scaffolding to reach each learners individual needs.

question.name: s2
question.questiontext: True or False: Learning preferences play a role in a student's learning but should not be taken into consideration when planning lessons.

answer.feedback: Although this statement correctly asserts that learners have different preferences, it is false that this should be disregarded when developing a lesson. Some learners prefer saying and doing things, observing demonstrations, writing everything down, working individually, or working with others in a group to name a few a learning preferences, and it is crucial to provide a variety of ways in our lessons for learners to engage with the material.

Correct! Some learners prefer saying and doing things, observing demonstrations, writing everything down, working individually, or working with others in a group to name a few a learning preferences. It is crucial to provide a variety of ways in our lessons for learners to engage with the material.

question.name: s3
question.questiontext: Which of the following practices is not a learner-centered strategy regarding the learner's first language?

answer.answertext: Providing opportunities for peer support based on first language
Asking that only English and its grammar rules be discussed in the classroom
answer.feedback: Correct! Although developing English skills is the goal, other languages are invaluable resources to that end in the classroom, and by showing its value in the classroom and allowing learners to compare and contrast the practices and rules of English and their first language, the learner can have a higher level of engagement with the lesson.

question.name: s4
question.questiontext: Which of the following is an example of making classroom interactions and tasks authentic?

answer.answertext: Only using English texts that are simplified to a specific reading level
Automatically using texts and topics that have worked in the past
Promoting roles and relevant texts that replicate or integrate the real world
answer.feedback: Correct! Incorporating authentic materials and tasks mean bringing in real world materials that are not oversimplified for specific teaching purposes. Authentic materials like community resources, printed bus schedules, or the day's weather forecast can be taught alongside textbooks and teacher-made materials to help learners make the connections between the classroom lessons and the outside world.

answer.answertext: Choosing real world materials based on the websites and community organizations that you go to
answer.feedback: Correct! Although developing English skills is the goal, other languages are invaluable resources to that end in the classroom, and by showing its value in the classroom and allowing learners to compare and contrast the practices and rules of English and their first language, the learner can have a higher level of engagement with the lesson.

question.name: s5
question.questiontext: According to Bloom's Taxonomy of Higher Order Thinking, which of the following levels of thinking is the highest?

answer.feedback: Correct! According to Bloom's Taxonomy of Higher Order Thinking, creating is at the top of the pyramid. Other corresponding actions for this skill include designing, constructing, and producing.

question.name: q6
question.questiontext: True or False: Only intermediate and advanced students can engage in higher-order thinking activities, such as analyzing, comparing, and organizing.

answer.feedback: Correct! This statement is false. Although it might seem easier to integrate higher order thinking skills in higher level English classes, incorporating these more engaging skills into each lesson is just as important in lower level classes. As we saw in the sample One-Question Survey Task in Unit 3, even high beginners can analyze information and create a graph to show the results of a class survey.

question.name: s7
question.questiontext: When teaching a multilevel class, it is important to differentiate by which of the following?

answer.answertext: All of the above
answer.feedback:
Correct! Our job as educators is to make adjustments in our classes based on the wide variety of learner profiles in our classes. To effectively differentiate instruction, multilevel teachers should consider the content, process, and products of instruction. 

In order to differentiate content, you can adjust the level and complexity of the content and language with more novice and more expert versions of materials. You can also adjust the modality of the materials you choose with some written, some oral and some print or digital. Finally, you sometimes can give learners a choice of topics within a larger theme.

You can also differentiate process through the instructional decisions that you make, the types of tasks you expect learners to engage with in your lessons, and the approach and learning tasks you use to help learners make sense of the content.

Finally, you can differentiate the end products or assessments that show learners achievement of learning outcomes, such as requiring an essay for some students while assigning a presentation for others.

answer.answertext: None of the above

question.name: s8
question.questiontext: Which of the following language support questions and frames might an effective teacher use to encourage learning?

answer.answertext: "What do you think about...?"
"We all seem to agree that..."
"What makes you say..."
All of the above
answer.feedback: Correct! All of these frames can be used to fortify learner output. These questions and frames invite classmates to contribute to discussion, elaborate on ideas, share opinions, and/or synthesize ideas.

answer.answertext: None of the above

question.name: s9
question.questiontext: True or False: Communicate Competence occurs when the student has a firm grasp of grammar and vocabulary.

answer.feedback: Correct! Communicative Competence entails far more than knowing grammar and vocabulary. It entails having sufficient command of the language to communicate effectively in a wide range of contexts, to read and write for different purposes, to comprehend and produce spoken language, and to use strategies to communicate more effectively, and repair breakdowns in communication.
